task.title: Remove stains
task.shortdesc: Stains of ink, grease, wine, and many others. Learn how to remove marks and regain the original blossom of your furniture.

taskbody.prereq: If the stain is already dry and the furniture has a raw finish please follow step 1. If it's an ink stain please follow step 4.
taskbody.context:
You've found many rings in a suspicious shade of red on your new solid wood table from . That must have been the good red wine last night. In the dim candlelight and in the lively conversation with the best friend, the attention was obviously not so much on the wonderfully grained table top. What to do? Luckily there's Stefan, the carpenter!
There're differences in the treatment of raw surfaces and varnished wood. The latter is especially insensitive to stains, as the varnish protects them from moisture for longer. A moist cloth is enough to clean the stain on a varnished item. Here're Stefan's ultimate tips for removing red wine and other stains from raw wood.
wine spilled on a wooden surface

step.cmd: In case of dried stains moisten such with a standard window cleaner. To do this, as a first step put the cleaner on a cotton cloth. Another way of bleaching is to use lemon juice. It's weaker than the solution at step 4 but also less dangerous.
Rub it into the affected area.

image.alt: an agent rubbed into a stain

info.note: Always work in the direction of the grain and careful small circular movements, so you get the best results and don't damage the natural structure of the wood so much.

step.cmd: After a short drying time, you can repeat the procedure. Then, despite the solution you've chosen please follow step 5.
If you fill professional even more effective way of bleaching is to use 3% hydrogen peroxide mixed with ammonia, which is available in pharmacies. Follow the step 2 to 5 if you decide to use it.

info.note: Although it's especially effective for ink stains, it works for many other stains including dried ones.
Stefan warns of the risk of chemical burns so always work with a protective mask and safety gloves. You should test beforehand in an inconspicuous place how the wood reacts to the solution.

step.cmd: If the stain hasn't completely faded, you can try using abrasives. This can be commercially available scouring milk, but also handwashing paste or a coarser toothpaste. Please follow step 6 if you have chosen to use one of the above.

p.note: Please pay attention to the colors of the agents that could also remain in the wood.

step.cmd: Apply the chosen agent generously to the stains overnight and leave to soak.
The next day, apply again this abrasive to a cloth accordingly to the stain's intensity.
First, rub the stain thoroughly and then lightly rough the entire surface to even the color.
Now you've to sand the area with fine sandpaper (150-180 mm).
After this process, clean again with the scouring milk and wash off well.
To nourish and smooth the wood structure, put a wood oil, olive oil, or other household oil on a soft cloth and distribute it well. Remove excess oil and repeat this process once or twice.

taskbody.result:
After removing the stain, it's important to treat the entire surface with fine sandpaper and finish with staining, waxing, or oiling. The treated area is less noticeable and the valuable furniture looks new again.
